item.title: Middle-earth Strategy Battle Game Path of Cirith Ungol First Look - We Loves Them!
item.content:encoded:
There are few moments in The Lord of the Rings quite as harrowing as when Gollum leads Sam and Frodo into the lair of Shelob, the horrifying Spider-like creature and offspring of Ungoliant who snares and webs the poor Hobbits. Games Workshop has sent us an all-new feature box called Path of Cirith Ungol: Shelob & Gollum to check out, along with the newest Swan Knights of Dol Amroth. We checked out the sprues, so follow along for this first sneak peek!

Path of Cirith Ungol: Shelob & Gollum

First up is this wonderful new box set, Path of Cirith Ungol: Shelob & Gollum, which features Shelob and Gollum both in brand-new poses. It also, importantly, features a very sad figure: Frodo unconscious and tied up in Shelob's webbing! There was a previous box set called In the Clutches of Shelob, which included Shelob and Sam (with webbed up Frodo), but this new set swaps out Sam for Gollum.

I love the new pose for Shelob included in this box set, which sees her crawling across a small crevasse of rocks, ready to strike. The previous model of Shelob had her rearing up on her hind legs, ready to strike. But this pose looks much more menacing, presenting her as the creeping terror she truly is.

Gollum also has another very gollum-y pose, perched on rocks and ready to strike (or scheme). This box set releases alongside a new book of scenarios all around Gollum, the Hobbits, and Shelob, entitled The Treachery of Gollum, which will present scenarios where players can reenact their favorite moments from the story. 

From trying to steal the ring from a sleeping Frodo and Sam, to this pivotal confrontation with Shelob, there will be lots to explore.

I wasn't able to get my hands on an advanced copy of this new book, so I can't speak to updated rules for the figures or the scenarios, but needless to say I'm thrilled for its eventual release in a few weeks.

As for poor ol' master Frodo, he'll be stuck in place in his webbing, with this model to be used as an objective marker in the Bravery of Master Samwise scenario found in the new book. Now let's take a closer look at how the figures come on the sprue.

Looking over the assembly instructions, I appreciate the simplicity and straightforward nature of these sprues. The Shelob model, which could have been overly complicated, looks clean and streamlined, without the need to assemble five pieces per leg.

And Frodo simply couldn't look more pathetic on the sprue - don't you just want to swoop in and save the little guy?

Swan Knights of Dol Amroth

I don't know why, but Prince Imrahil is one of my favorite characters from The Lord of the Rings, with very little time on the page (and no time in the films), he swoops in at the last minute with his Swan Knights to help save the day. Now, a new set of those very same Swan Knights are available from Games Workshop!

Cast in resin, these will be trickier to assemble than plastic miniatures. I, for one, have no patience, and use super-glue and a quick-dry solvent spray to put them together immediately. But more practiced and careful builders love the flexibility that gluing with super glue gives you, and more power to them!

Let's dive into the sprues on these models and see what we're working with here.

The detailing on these knights is really quite incredible, I especially like their armor and plating, which sets them apart from other Middle-earth Strategy Battle Game men-at-arms by having a more regal, well-equipped look to them. 

These are fighting men with the training and coin to come to the battlefield ready to deliver a decisive blow (or at least help deliver that decisive blow).

What do you think of these new models? Will you be checking them out and adding them to your Middle-earth Strategy Battle Game collection? Let me know in the comments below! Pre-sale opens up as of this article going live, so be sure to head over to Games Workshop to check it out!

The Middle-earth Strategy Battle Game units used in the creation of this review were provided by Games Workshop.

Giaco Furino joined the TechRaptor team as a Staff Writer in 2019 after searching for a dedicated place to write and talk about Tabletop Games. In 2020, heâ€¦ More about Giaco
